column3: One way that the factory would use or cover up spoiled meat was to pickle them, rub it with soda to make it smell better (ot any smell of their choosing), and then sell it to people. " ...the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters...the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose.". The factory would also pump a second type of stronger pickle to kill the odor of spoiled meat and smoke it. "pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor...after the hams had been smoked...". The factory would also replace the bad part, typically the bone, with a white hot iron , turning all the meat into Number One Grade. " ...they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade.".
column4: Sure, here is the reworked passage:  "The factory would utilize several methods to cover up and salvage spoiled meat. They would pickle the meat to mask any unpleasant smells, then rub it with soda to modify its smell. This practice would give them the means to sell the spoiled meat under a different name, without anyone noticing the changes.  As a further step, the factory would employ a stronger pickle to eliminate any lingering smells of spoiled meat. This method would involve injecting the strong pickle into the meat, which would break down the chemical compounds responsible for the bad smells. This process allowed the factory to transform spoiled meat into Number One Grade, regardless of its initial quality."

column3: There were a few different social classes involved in the Egyptains government. The pharaoh is the leader, believed to be gods by their people. The text says, "Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods.", so thats what the priests did. The pharaoh also had a vizier, which was the highest  official below the pharaoh, as it says if you click the 7. There were soldiers who fought in wars or stopped wars. The text says, "During long periods of peace, soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building such structures as pyramids and palaces."
column4: The Egyptian government system had a hierarchy of social classes with the pharaoh at the top, followed by powerful nobles and priests. The nobles held government positions, while priests were responsible for pleasing the gods. The Pharaoh also had a Vizier, who held the highest official position below the Pharaoh. Soldiers played a significant role in both war and peace, supervising the peasants and farmers who were responsible for building the monuments associated with the pyramids and palaces.

column3: Aristotle describes tragedy with three elements that would build the conflict in the story.  First there must be a hero that is flawed. This flaw would eventually lead to the hero's downfall. This would create the conflict of the story.  Then there is a pooint were the hero has  realization about himself or his life that will guide the story either left of right. It is at this point were the character reflect on themselves and turn things. Finally there is a turn in fate were the hero goes into a final tragedy.  This will be how the story ends with a fall in fortune that make the story what it is.
column4: Aristotle's analysis of tragedy was built on three core elements. First, a hero with a flaw would arise, escalating a conflict that would fuel the story's progression. Secondly, the hero's self-revelation, or epiphany, would serve as a turning point in the narrative, prompting a shift in perspective. Finally, a tragic turn of events would lead to the hero's ultimate demise, propelling the story to a dramatic climax.

column3: The Chicago meatpacking industry was exposed for public distribution of spoiled meat that was altered to look like regular meat by using chemistry and mixtures. For example, if meat is discovered to be sour after being taken from the pickle, it is rubbed with soda to take the smell away. Chemistry was also practiced to choose the color, flavor, and odor of the ruined meat (paragraph 2). This meant that to successfully cover up the unsanitary meat sold to the public, chemistry was practiced to make it look healthy. In addition, chemical combinations, such as borax and glycerin, were added to spoiled meat and dumped back into the hopper to be sold to the public (paragraph 3). They were able to not only preserve the moldy meat with borax, but also mixed it in with fresh meats to cover up the taste or smell of spoiled meat. Upton Sinclair was able to expose the meatpacking industry for using chemistry and mixtures to cover up the spoiled meat that was reused and sold to the public.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:    "The meatpacking industry employed deceptive tactics to disguise spoiled meat for public distribution. column3: According to Aristotle, one element of an ideal tragedy is that it should incite feelings of pity and fear within us. Aristotle believes that a good tragedy doesn't just show for the spectacle, but truly makes us feel for the characters, and incites those feelings of pity and fear.  As Aristotle states, "It follows plainly, in the first place, that the change of fortune presented must not be the spectacle of a virtuous man brought from prosperity to adversity: for this moves neither pity nor fear." Aristotle also believes that another element of the ideal tragedy does not feature a turn from bad to good, but instead should feature the reverse and should go from good to bad. He believes that this turn should be brought about by a crucial mistake made by a character. The third element of an ideal tragedy is one with a single issue as its plot. Aristotle compares those with a "double threat of plot", like the Odyssey, as second rank. He believes that it is only considered the best because of the weakness of the audience. A true poet doesn't write just based on the wishes of the audience and because of that misses the true tragic pleasure of an ideal tragedy.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  According to Aristotle, a tragedy should evoke feelings of pity and fear in the audience. A tragedy should not only depict the spectacle, but should also make the audience feel for the characters and trigger these emotions of pity and fear. Aristotle emphasizes that a tragedy should not revert from good to bad, but rather should feature the reverse where a character suffers a downfall caused by a critical mistake. Additionally, Aristotle believes that a tragedy should feature only a single central conflict in its plot.  Furthermore, Aristotle also believes that a tragedy should be considered a superior form of art only when it is weak in its audience's interests. A true poet, according to Aristotle, creates a tragedy not based on the dictates of the audience but rather based on their deep understanding of the human condition.
